properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frequent Snow squalls producing near zero visibilities are expected to continue today and tonight. Locations: Corner Brook and Bay St. George. Time Span: Today and tonight. Snowfall accumulations: Generally 2 to 4 cm, but as much as 20 cm in snow squalls. Remarks: Snow squalls are expected to diminish overnight tonight, but there a possibility they may linger into early Friday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-21T04:02:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-20T12:03:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2023434970.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will bring snow and strong southerly winds to the Haines Road and South Klondike Highway today. Total snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm are expected through tonight. The strong winds will also create widespread blowing snow with poor visibilities. The snow and winds are forecast to ease somewhat by Friday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-21T10:58:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-20T18:59:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0535799851.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls gradually weakening today. Snow squalls will continue this morning before gradually weakening through the day. Local snowfall amounts in the 5 to 10 cm range will be possible by the time the snow squalls come to an end. Visibilities will be reduced at times in heavy snow and blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Occasional snow squalls producing poor visibility in blowing snow will continue. Locations: inland portions along the Bugero Highway, the Bay D'Espoir area, and the Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: tonight. Additional snowfall accumulations: 2 to 4 cm in snow squalls. Remarks: Snow squalls are expected to taper off overnight tonight or early Friday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Vernon because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-21T00:04:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-02-20T10:48:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3371971889.2020
Area: North Okanagan

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A developing weather system is tracking along the Arctic mainland coast and is forecast to give blizzard conditions at times to Cambridge Bay starting this morning. This event is expected to end this evening as winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: between 5 and 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: westerly near 70 km/h. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: Persistent flurries will combine with strong westerly winds to cause blizzard like conditions at times in blowing snow today and tonight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist into this morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canadas website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministre de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montral, visit the Rseau de surveillance de la qualit de lair de la Ville de Montrals website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Qubec, visit the Ministre de la Sant et des Services sociauxs website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction rgionale de sant publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lle-de-Montral at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-20T20:39:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministre de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministre de la Sant et des Services sociaux, the Direction rgionale de sant publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lle-de-Montral, the City of Montral, 2020-02-20T04:41:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2784912339.2020
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quvillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Occasional snowsqualls producing poor visibility in blowing snow expected today and tonight. Locations: Port Aux Basques, Gros Morne to Hawkes Bay, Deer Lake, Green Bay - White Bay, Buchans and the Interior. Time Span: Today and tonight. Snowfall accumulations: Generally trace amounts, but as much as 2 to 4 cm in snow squalls. Remarks: Snow squalls are expected to diminish overnight tonight, but there a possibility they may linger into early Friday morning. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-21T04:04:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-20T12:05:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4133151936.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Buchans and the interior, Green Bay - White Bay, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow continue. A low pressure system moving along the Arctic mainland coast continues to give strong easterly winds and blizzard conditions to Ulukhaktok. The wind will begin to ease late this afternoon and blizzard conditions will end. While the visibility will improve late this afternoon, some blowing snow may continue at times this evening, overnight and into Friday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-21T00:59:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-20T17:32:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2544622942.2020
Area: Ulukhaktok
